Title.evidence: This article intends to review the role of EVAR in the management of elective AAA.

Participants.evidence: Prospective randomised controlled trials (RCTs) comparing EVAR with OSR in individuals with AAA considered fit for surgery.

Intervention.evidence: comparing EVAR with OSR in individuals with AAA considered fit for surgery.

Objective.evidence: To assess the effectiveness of EVAR versus conventional OSR in individuals with AAA considered fit for surgery, and EVAR versus best medical care in those considered unfit for surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: short‐term mortality (including 30‐day or inhospital mortality, excluding deaths prior to intervention) with EVAR to be significantly lower than with OSR

Number_Randomised.evidence: Four high‐quality trials comparing EVAR with OSR (n = 2790) and one high‐quality trial comparing EVAR with no intervention (n = 404)

Number_Analysed.evidence: a pooled analysis, including 1362 individuals randomised to EVAR and 1361 randomised to OSR

Result_Outcome.evidence: short‐term mortality (including 30‐day or inhospital mortality, excluding deaths prior to intervention) with EVAR to be significantly lower than with OSR (1.4% versus 4.2%, OR 0.33, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.20 to 0.55; P < 0.0001)

Harms.evidence: there was a slightly higher incidence of pulmonary complications in the OSR group compared with the EVAR group (OR 0.36, 95% CI 0.17 to 0.75; P = 0.006)
